tit.e: Shingu (votive objects for a Shinto home shrine)
Shingu (votive objects for a Shinto home shrine)
tit.cmt: タイトルですので、カッコ内の補足は削除しました。

sen.j: 神具（しんぐ）とは、神道の祭祀に用いられる道具または器具をいう。
sen.e: "Shingu" refers to tools or utensils used for Shinto religious services.
"Shingu" refers to tools or utensils used for Shinto religious services.
"Shingu" refers to tools or utensils used for Shinto religious services.

sen.j: 作られる素材としては、木製のものは白木で作られることが多く、そのほか金属製（真鍮）、白い陶器が使われることが多い。
sen.e: Wooden ones are often made of plain wood, and others are often made of metal (brass) or white earthenware.
Wooden ones are often made of plain wood, and others are often made of metal (brass) or white earthenware.
Wooden ones are often made of plain wood, and others are often made of metal (brass) or white earthenware.

sen.j: 主な神具
sen.e: Main shingu
Main shingu
Main shingu

sen.j: ここであげた神具は主なものであり、神社（氏神の神社や信仰する神社）や教派神道各派によっては必要なもの・不要なものがあることから神社や教派神道各派の教会、神具店（神具を扱う仏具店）に相談する必要がある。
sen.e: The shingu listed here are the main ones, and depending on the shrine (shrine of the ujigami (a guardian god or spirit of a particular place in the Shinto religion) or the shrine of worship) and Sect Shinto school, some things are necessary/unnecessary, so seek the advice of shrines, churches of Sect Shinto school, and shingu stores (butsugu (Buddhist altar fittings) stores carrying shingu).

The shingu listed here are the main ones, and depending on the shrine (shrine of the ujigami (a guardian god or spirit of a particular place in the Shinto religion) or the shrine of worship) and Sect Shinto school, some things are necessary/unnecessary, so seek the advice of shrines, churches of Sect Shinto school, and shingu stores (butsugu (Buddhist altar fittings) stores carrying shingu).

The shingu listed here are the main ones, and depending on the shrine (shrine of the ujigami (a guardian god or spirit of a particular place in the Shinto religion) or the shrine of worship) and Sect Shinto school, some things are necessary/unnecessary, so seek the advice of shrines, churches of Sect Shinto school, and shingu stores (butsugu (Buddhist altar fittings) stores carrying shingu).

sen.j: 神棚
sen.e: Kamidana (a household Shinto altar)
Kamidana (a household Shinto altar)
Kamidana (a household Shinto altar)

sen.j: 主に壁の上方に天井からつしたり、鴨居を利用したりして作られ、東向きまたは南向きに作られることが多い。
sen.e: They are often hung from the ceiling, high on the wall, or built using the kamoi (a generic term for a head jamb, normally have tracks for sliding doors or partitions), facing east of south.
They are often hung from the ceiling, high on the wall, or built using the kamoi (a generic term for a head jamb, normally have tracks for sliding doors or partitions), facing southeast.
They are often hung from the ceiling, high on the wall, or built using the kamoi (a generic term for a head jamb, normally have tracks for sliding doors or partitions), facing south or east.
sen.cmt: south or east としました。

sen.j: なお、神棚が作れない場合は、箪笥などの上を利用して作られることもある。
sen.e: When kamidana cannot be built, it is sometimes built using the top of tansu (chest of drawers).
When kamidana cannot be built, it is sometimes built using the top of tansu (chest of drawers).
When kamidana cannot be built, it is sometimes built using the top of tansu (chest of drawers).

sen.j: 宮形（みやがた）
sen.e: Miyagata
Miyagata
Miyagata

sen.j: 神社の社殿建築（本殿）を模して作られたもので、通常は白木で造られる。
sen.e: It is built imitating the architecture of the main building of a Shinto shrine (Honden (main hall)), and is generally made with plain wood.
It is built imitating the architecture of the main building of a Shinto shrine (Honden (main hall)), and is generally made with plain wood.
It is built imitating the architecture of the main building of a Shinto shrine (Honden (main hall)), and is generally made with plain wood.

sen.j: 一社造り、三社造り、七社造りなどがあるほか、神明造りや箱に入ったような箱宮などもある。
sen.e: Other than the issha zukuri (one shrine), sansha zukuri (three shrines), and nanasha zukuri (seven shrines), there are Shinmei tsukuri (style of shrine architecture based on that of Ise-jingu Shrine) and hakomiya (box shrine), which looks like a shrine in a box.

Other than the issha zukuri (one shrine), sansha zukuri (three shrines), and nanasha zukuri (seven shrines), there are Shinmei tsukuri (style of shrine architecture based on that of Ise-jingu Shrine) and hakomiya (box shrine), which looks like a shrine in a box.

Other than the issha zukuri (one shrine), sansha zukuri (three shrines), and nanasha zukuri (seven shrines), there are Shinmei tsukuri (style of shrine architecture based on that of Ise-jingu Shrine) and hakomiya (box shrine), which looks like a shrine in a box.

sen.j: 通常の家庭では、一社造りまたは三社造りの宮形が使用されることが多い。
sen.e: In normal homes, issha zukuri or sansha zukuri miyagata are commonly used.
In normal homes, issha zukuri or sansha zukuri miyagata are commonly used.
In normal homes, issha zukuri or sansha zukuri miyagata are commonly used.

sen.j: 神札（大麻）の祀り方としては、一社造りでは伊勢神宮（天照皇大神宮）の神札（大麻という）を一番前にして氏神神社の神札、日常信仰する神社の神札の順で祀る。
sen.e: Regarding the enshrinement of the talisman (taima (amulet)), in issha zukuri, the talisman of Ise-jingu Shrine (Amaterasu-kotaijingu Shrine) is enshrined at the very front, and then the talisman of the Ujigami-jinja Shrine and the talisman of the shrine routinely worshipped, in this order.

Regarding the enshrinement of the talisman (taima (amulet)), in issha zukuri, the talisman of Ise-jingu Shrine (Amaterasu-kotaijingu Shrine) is enshrined at the very front, and then the talisman of the Ujigami-jinja Shrine and the talisman of the shrine routinely worshipped, in this order.

Regarding the enshrinement of the talisman (taima (amulet)), in issha zukuri, the talisman of Ise-jingu Shrine (Amaterasu-kotaijingu Shrine) is enshrined at the very front, and then the talisman of the Ujigami-jinja Shrine and the talisman of the shrine routinely worshipped, in this order.

sen.j: 三社造りでは中央に伊勢神宮の神札（大麻）を祀り、向かって右に氏神神社の神札、左に日常信仰する神社の神札を祀る。
sen.e: In sansha zukuri, the talisman (taima) of Ise-jingu Shrine is enshrined in the center, and the talisman of the Ujigami-jinja Shrine to the right, and the talisman of the shrine routinely worshipped to the left.

In sansha zukuri, the talisman (taima) of Ise-jingu Shrine is enshrined in the center, and the talisman of the Ujigami-jinja Shrine to the right, and the talisman of the shrine routinely worshipped to the left.

In sansha zukuri, the talisman (taima) of Ise-jingu Shrine is enshrined in the center, and the talisman of the Ujigami-jinja Shrine to the right, and the talisman of the shrine routinely worshipped to the left.

sen.j: 注連縄（しめなわ）
sen.e: Shimenawa (sacred rice-straw ropes)
Shimenawa (sacred rice-straw ropes)
Shimenawa (sacred rice-straw ropes)

sen.j: 稲藁で作られた縄に四本の紙垂（しで）を垂らしたもので、神棚の上方に取り付けられる。
sen.e: It is a rope made of rice straw with four shide (chain of cut white paper suspended from the straw rope marking off a sacred area of a Shinto shrine) suspended and attached to the upper area of the kamidana.

It is a rope made of rice straw with four shide (chain of cut white paper suspended from the straw rope marking off a sacred area of a Shinto shrine) suspended and attached to the upper area of the kamidana.

It is a rope made of rice straw with four shide (chain of cut white paper suspended from the straw rope marking off a sacred area of a Shinto shrine) suspended and attached to the upper area of the kamidana.

sen.j: 神鏡
sen.e: Shinkyo (divine mirror)
Shinkyo (divine mirror)
Shinkyo (divine mirror)

sen.j: 円形の薄い鏡で、通常鏡を支える台とともに用いられる。
sen.e: It is a round thin mirror, generally used along with a base for supporting the mirror.
It is a round thin mirror, generally used along with a base for supporting the mirror.
It is a round thin mirror, generally used along with a base for supporting the mirror.

sen.j: 三方 (神道)
sen.e: Sanho (a stand to place offerings) (Shinto)
Sanho (a stand to place offerings) (Shinto)
Sanho (a stand to place offerings) (Shinto)

sen.j: 神饌や神酒・水を供えるために用いられる白木造りの台。
sen.e: A base made of plain wood used to offer food and alcohol offering to the gods, sacred wine, sake, and water.
A base made of plain wood used to offer food and alcohol offering to the gods, sacred wine, sake, and water.
A base made of plain wood used to offer food and alcohol offering to the gods, sacred wine, sake, and water.

sen.j: 神器
sen.e: Jingi (the sacred treasures)
Jingi (the sacred treasures)
Jingi (the sacred treasures)

sen.j: 神に供える水や塩・神酒を入れるための器で、白い陶器で作られることが多い。
sen.e: A bowl for offering water, salt, or sacred wine or sake to the gods, often made of white earthenware.
A bowl for offering water, salt, or sacred wine or sake to the gods, often made of white earthenware.
A bowl for offering water, salt, or sacred wine or sake to the gods, often made of white earthenware.

sen.j: 米・塩
sen.e: Rice and salt
Rice and salt
Rice and salt:
sen.cmt: コロンを追加しました。

sen.j: －平瓮
sen.e: - hiraka clay vessel
- hiraka clay vessel
Hiraka clay vessel

sen.j: 神酒
sen.e: Sacred wine or sake
Sacred wine or sake
Sacred wine or sake:
sen.cmt: コロンを追加しました。

sen.j: －瓶子
sen.e: - wine bottle
- wine bottle
Wine bottle

sen.j: 水
sen.e: Water
Water
Water:
sen.cmt: コロンを追加しました。

sen.j: －水器
sen.e: - water bowl
- water bowl
Water bowl

sen.j: 灯明
sen.e: Tomyo (light offered to god)
Tomyo (light offered to god)
Tomyo (light offered to god)

sen.j: 三本の棒を組み合わせた脚をつけた灯明皿または燭台が用いられる。
sen.e: Tomyo plate or candlestand with legs made of three combined sticks are used.
Tomyo plate or candlestand with legs made of three combined sticks are used.
Tomyo plate or candlestand with legs made of three combined sticks are used.

sen.j: 榊立て
sen.e: Sakaki (species of evergreen sacred to Shinto) stand
Sakaki (species of evergreen sacred to Shinto) stand
Sakaki (species of evergreen sacred to Shinto) stand

sen.j: 榊を供えるための陶器製の花立と、白木または陶器製の井桁がセットでもいいられることが多い。
sen.e: A flower vase made of earthenware for offering sakaki and a grid made of plain wood or earthenware are often used as a set.
A flower vase made of earthenware for offering sakaki and a grid made of plain wood or earthenware are often used as a set.
A flower vase made of earthenware for offering sakaki and a grid made of plain wood or earthenware are often used as a set.

sen.j: 祖霊舎（御霊屋・神徒檀）
sen.e: Soreisha (mitamaya, shintodan alter)
Soreisha (mitamaya, shintodan alter)
Soreisha (mitamaya, shintodan alter)

sen.j: 神棚が神を祭るものに対し、各家庭の先祖代々の霊を祀るためのものである。
sen.e: While kamidana enshrines god, this enshrines the ancestral spirits of households.
While kamidana enshrines god, this enshrines the ancestral spirits of households.
While kamidana enshrines god, this enshrines the ancestral spirits of households.

sen.j: 霊璽（れいじ）
sen.e: Reiji (spirit vessel)
Reiji (spirit vessel)
Reiji (spirit vessel)

sen.j: 仏教における位牌に相当するもので、故人の霊の依り代となるものとされ、通常白木で造られる。
sen.e: Corresponding to ihai (ancestral tablets) in Buddhism, it is considered the yorishiro (object representative of a divine spirit) of the spirit of the deceased, and is generally made of plain wood.
Corresponding to ihai (ancestral tablets) in Buddhism, it is considered the yorishiro (object representative of a divine spirit) of the spirit of the deceased, and is generally made of plain wood.
Corresponding to ihai (ancestral tablets) in Buddhism, it is considered the yorishiro (object representative of a divine spirit) of the spirit of the deceased, and is generally made of plain wood.

sen.j: 位牌と同じく故人一人ひとりに作られるものと、繰り出し位牌のように数人の故人をまてめた霊璽もある。
sen.e: As with ihai, some are made individually for each of the deceased, while other reiji are for several deceased, as with kuridashi-ihai.
As with ihai, some are made individually for each of the deceased, while other reiji are for several deceased, as with kuridashi-ihai.
As with ihai, some are made individually for each of the deceased, while other reiji are for several deceased, as with kuridashi-ihai.

sen.j: なお、霊璽には位牌と異なり霊璽を覆うカバーのようなものがある。
sen.e: Furthermore, unlike ihai, reiji has a cover for covering the reiji.
Furthermore, unlike ihai, reiji has a cover for covering the reiji.
Furthermore, unlike ihai, reiji has a cover for covering the reiji.

sen.j: そのほかの神具
sen.e: Other shingu
Other shingu
Other shingu

sen.j: 案（あん）
sen.e: An table
An table
An table

sen.j: 主に神道における行事（結婚式や地鎮祭など）で使用されるもので、白木で作られた机である。
sen.e: Mainly used in Shinto events (weddings and ground-breaking ceremonies), it is a table made of plain wood.
Mainly used in Shinto events (weddings and ground-breaking ceremonies), it is a table made of plain wood.
Mainly used in Shinto events (weddings and ground-breaking ceremonies), it is a table made of plain wood.

sen.j: 通常片方に四本ずつ脚をもち、玉串や神饌などを置く台として使用される。
sen.e: It usually has four legs on each side, and is used as a table to place tamagushi (branch of a sacred tree), food and alcohol offering to the gods, etc.
It usually has four legs on each side, and is used as a table to place tamagushi (branch of a sacred tree), food and alcohol offering to the gods, etc.
It usually has four legs on each side, and is used as a table to place tamagushi (branch of a sacred tree), food and alcohol offering to the gods, etc.

sen.j: 大幣（大麻）
sen.e: Onusa (a wooden wand used in Shinto rituals) (taima)
Onusa (a wooden wand used in Shinto rituals) (taima)
Onusa (a wooden wand used in Shinto rituals) (taima)

sen.j: 人形（ひとがた）・形代（かたしろ）
sen.e: Hitogata (person of straw), katashiro (paper doll used in Shinto purification rites)
Hitogata (person of straw), katashiro (paper doll used in Shinto purification rites)
Hitogata (person of straw), katashiro (paper doll used in Shinto purification rites)

sen.j: 鈴・神楽鈴
sen.e: Suzu (bell), kagurasuzu (bell for Kagura (Shinto music and dance numbers))
Suzu (bell), kagurasuzu (bell for Kagura (Shinto music and dance numbers))
Suzu (bell), kagurasuzu (bell for Kagura (Shinto music and dance numbers))

sen.j: 鳥居
sen.e: Torii (an archway to a Shinto shrine)
Torii (an archway to a Shinto shrine)
Torii (an archway to a Shinto shrine)
